title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) – On a night where the final score told only a fraction of the story, Dominique Wilkins authored a masterpiece. The human highlight film, now wearing Atlanta Hawks white at the venerable Omni, turned back the clock with a force that shook the very foundations of the building, pouring in a game-high 47 points to power the Hawks to a 105-95 victory over the rival Boston Celtics.

From the opening tip, this was the Wilkins Show. He was a whirlwind of motion, a symphony of soaring dunks and silky jumpers that the Celtics, for all their history, had no answer for. He attacked the rim with a ferocity that defied his years, each basket chipping away at Boston’s resolve. While the Celtics’ balance—with Dee Brown’s 23 points and Rick Fox’s 20—kept them within striking distance, they were merely a chorus to Wilkins’ solo.

Every time Boston threatened to close the gap, “Nique” answered. A thunderous slam to silence a run. A clutch three to extinguish hope. His 47 points were not just a number on a stat sheet; they were a declaration, a relentless assault that carried his team on his back.

The supporting cast played its part perfectly. Mookie Blaylock orchestrated the offense with 12 assists, and Christian Laettner provided a steadying presence with 14 points. But this night belonged irrevocably to one man. As the final seconds ticked away on the Hawks' win, the roar of the Atlanta crowd was not just for a victory over a storied foe, but a standing ovation for a historic, singular performance from their legendary star. In a career defined by breathtaking moments, this 47-point tour de force was one of his most dominant.
